title: 12 Mile Limit
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a lemon twist.
description: The 12 mile limit is a prohibition era cocktail that was named after the 12 mile distance at sea you had to be at to drink alcohol during the Volstead Act.

title: 3 Dots and a Dash
instruction: Combine everything into a blender and blend at high speed for about 5 seconds. Pour into a tall glass and garnish with 3 cherries and a pineapple spear (can also stick the a blade of the pineapple in there). The three cherries are your three "dots" and the spear is the "dash."
description: A Donn Beach tiki cocktail design out of World War II, "3 dots and a dash" signifies V for Victory in morse code. The letter V in morse code is ...- and this cocktail's garnish represents the three dots and the dash

title: 50/50 Martini
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled (usually 2 minutes). Strain into a chilled nick and nora glass and, optionally, garnish with lemon twist.
description: The concept of the 50/50 was to go into the opposite direction of a "dry martini", which is to use less dry vermouth. So, to make your martini less dry you had more dry vermouth to counter your dry gin. Yet, this still isn't sweet.

title: 5th Amendment
instruction:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir until chilled (usually about 2 minutes). Strain over fresh ice into an old fashioned glass. Rub a lemon peel around the edges of the glass and drop into the drink. Serve.
Note: You can use Velvet Falernum or Falernum Syrup for this recipe.
description: This herbal cocktail feels and tastes like a prohibition style drink but we feel it probably was invented many years later. We couldn't find any good history for it.

title: Air Mail
instruction: Build all ingredients except champagne in a cocktail shaker with ice, give it a healthy 10 second shake. Strain into a coupe or Nick & Nora glass and top with champagne (at least 1.5 oz). Historically garnished with a postage stamp, probably can be skipped for this one. If possible, use a light cuban rum.
description: This champagne drink brings the classic daiquiri appeal to a champagne cocktail for a well crafted design. Appears in David Embury's 1948 The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks.

title: Alabama Slammer
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over fresh ice into a highball and serve.
description: No doubt popularized in the 80's, the Alabama Slammer is a product of the 70's and probably defined as a shot to be "slammed", but it's a great cocktail in a tall glass!

title: Amaretto Sour
instruction:
Add all ingredients into your cocktail shaker. Because we're using egg white, dry shake (with no ice) the cocktail aggressively for 20 seconds. Add ice cubes and shake for an additional 15 seconds and strain over ice. Garnish and serve!
Jeffrey Morgenthaler suggests cask strength bourbon (higher proof stuff), it's definitely a great way to cut through all the flavor and give you bourbon intensity.
description: The Amaretto Sour is a highly requested cocktail made in a variation of ways; our way is the Jeffrey Morgenthaler design.

title: Amaro Manhattan
instruction: Add ingredients to stirring glass with ice and stir for 30 seconds to 1 minute until well chilled. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and optionally add a Luxardo Maraschino Cherry. Adding the cherry juice to your stir is also optional, if you're looking for a bit of added sweetness.
description: The Amaro Manhattan substitutes your favorite Amaro (for us, Bully Boy or Averna during the holidays) for vermouth.

title: Americano
instruction: Add each ingredient over ice into an old fashioned glass. Garnish with a lemon or orange twist.
description: A softer version of a Negroni, something to introduce a person to campari without being overly bitter.  First served in the 1860s at Gaspare Campari's bar in Milan, Italy. Found in Casino Royale as well.

title: Ancient Mariner
instruction:
Build all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Dump contents of shaker into a chilled old fashioned glass, garnish and serve!
Bonus points? Score your lime wedge to make it look fancy.
description: A tiki drink published by Jeff Berry in the Grog Log, brings together allspice, rums and that lovely flavor of demerara.

title: Ankle Breaker
instruction: Add all ingredients into your cocktail shaker, add crushed ice and shake for 10 seconds, dump contents into an old fashioned glass and serve.
description: A surprisingly delicious tiki cocktail from the wamp Fox Room of The Francis Marion Hotel in Charleston SC circa 1950

title: Aperol Spritz
instruction: Add ice to a wine / champagne glass and follow that up with Prosecco. Add Aperol and club soda and follow that up with your garnish and serve.
description: Invented in 1919 by the Barbieri brothers, it became trendy in the 1950's as an alternative to the white wine and soda.

title: Apricot Sour
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker without ice and shake aggressively for 20 seconds. Add your ice to the shaker and shake for another 15 seconds. Strain over ice into an old fashioned glass and serve.
description: Fruit brandy's have been popular for years, but usually they play a subtle role in a cocktail. The apricot sour plays a central role in this beverage.

title: Aviation
instruction: Add all the ingredients to a shaker and fill with ice. Shake for 15 seconds and strain into a chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a cherry if desired.
description: The Aviation was created by Hugo Ensslin, head bartender at the Hotel Wallick in New York, in the early twentieth century. The first published recipe for the drink appeared in Ensslin's 1916 Recipes for Mixed Drinks.

title: Aztec Sacrifice
instruction: Add all ingredients but ginger beer to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled nick and nora glass and top with ginger beer.
description: This cocktail was designed by Derrick and Jennifer Schommer of Common Man Cocktails with the goal of integrating an anejo tequila into a springy yet spicy and sweet tart cocktail design.

title: Bali Bali
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake aggressively for 15 seconds and strain over crushed ice into a tiki glass.
description: A 1950s recipe from Bali Ha'i At The Beach in New Orleans

title: Bamboo Screwdriver
instruction: Add all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 second. Strain over ice into an old fashioned glass.
description: We couldn't find any history on this, but we guess the screwdriver nature is the use of orange juice combined with a core spirit (rum) to make an excellent flavored cocktail.

title: Banana Daiquiri
instruction:
Cut and peal half a banana, add banana and all remaining ingredients into blender and blend for 10 seconds or until smooth.
Use your favorite rum for this drink, it makes a difference.
description: Created by Mariano Licudine of the Mai-Kai Restaurant, Fort Lauderdale FL in 1971. The Mai-Kai, opened December 1956, it's now registered as a Historic Place in the National Registers and is the last known tiki-themed restaurant serving original Don Beachcomber cocktail recipes.

title: Barmuda Triangle
instruction: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and serve.
description: While there is no real history behind this drink, nor do we know whom created it, this cocktail came across our desk and we just had to make it.

title: Bay Breeze
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain over fresh ice into a tall glass and garnish.
description: The bay breeze is a descendant of the Cape Codder and ancestor of the Sea Breeze, meaning drinks of this variation can be dated into the 1920s and 1930s, but grew up and became popular in the 1960s.

title: Beachcomber's Punch
instruction: Add all ingredients to a blender and blend for 5 seconds, pour into a champagne flute with additional crushed ice and garnish with mint. We suggest the "dash" of pernod / absinthe utilize about six drops.
description: A classic Donn The Beachcomber tiki cocktail circa 1930 at the original Hollywood bar.

title: Betsy Ross Cocktail
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled (usually around 2 minutes). Strain into a chilled coupe/martini glass and serve.
description: We're not sure if this cocktail has any real relation to Betsy Ross and her friend Washington  (and being the first to make the American Flag), but we have heard its first publishing was around 1941.

title: Bijou Cocktail
instruction:
Add ice to your Nick and Nora glass (our coupe/martini) with water and set aside. Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir for around two minutes. Dump cold water out of your glass and strain cocktail into your now chilled vessel.
Garnish with an olive or real maraschino cherry and serve.
Note: We have chose Harry Johnson's original recipe over Dale Degroffs re-balance because of the stronger chartreuse flavor profile without the lighter "watered down" feel of the additional gin.
description: A classic Harry Johnson recipe from his bartending manual from the 1900s.

title: Blood & Sand
instruction: Add all ingredients to a shaker and shake for 12 seconds, strain into a coupe, old fashioned glass (on ice), or Nick & Nora glass, whichever you prefer. Flame an orange peel over the beverage, rub the peel on the edge of the glass, and drop it into the drink.
description: We see very few scotch cocktails and like even less of them, but here is one named after Rudolph Valentino's 1922 bullfighter movie Blood and Sand. Apparently the “blood” represents Heering cherry liqueur, and the “sand” is for the orange juice.

title: Bloody Mary
instruction:
Build all ingredients in a cocktail shaker and shake for 10 seconds and strain over fresh ice into a tall glass. Garnish with celery stick and anything else you would love to see on top of your Bloody Mary.
Celery Bitters and Firewater Bitters optional ingredients that bring savory heat to your recipe.
description: The Bloody Mary’s original history isn’t very clear, but there have been a few folks that lay claim to its creation. Harry’s New York Bar in Paris believes they are the place the Bloody Mary was first invented in around 1921.

title: Blue Hawaii
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake aggressively for 12 seconds, strain over crushed ice into a highball glass or hurricane glass. Optionally, blend the cocktail and dump into your glass instead.
description: Invented in 1957 when a Bols rep asked Harry Yee, a bartender from Honolulu Hawai, to create a drink using Bols Blue Curacao. This drink is the final result of that challenge.

title: Blue Hawaiian
instruction: Add all ingredients to your cocktail shaker and give it a hard aggressive shake for 20 seconds. Strain over fresh ice into your highball glass, garnish with a pineapple and cherry.
description: A highly searched cocktail design that is no doubt a riff off the pina colada, but it's blue and has a slightly different flavor profile.

title: Boars Tooth
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake aggressively for 15 seconds and dump contents of shaker into your glass. Garnish with a lime wedge and maraschino cherry.
description: We found absolutely no reference to where this cocktail could have come from but we guess someone was playing with the concept of the pina colada and mai tai when working on this design.

title: Bocce Ball
instruction: Build all ingredients over ice in a tall glass and stir to integrate. Top with club soda, garnish and serve.
description: We're not entirely sure where the history of the bocce ball originated, probably the 1980s, but there are many variations, some with or without vodka. The core ingredients are orange juice and amaretto which pair strongly together.

title: Boulevardier
instruction:
Chill your old fashioned glass with ice and water and set aside. Add all ingredients with ice to a mixing glass and stir for 2 minutes. Dump your chilled water from the old fashioned glass and strain into chilled glass.
Rub an orange twist around the rim of the glass and drop into the glass. Serve.
description: The Boulevardier is named after a Magazine in France created by Erskine Gwynne called The Boulevardier from 1927 to 1932. It was created by Harry MacElhone of Harry's New York Bar in Paris, but he credits Erskine Gwynne with the creation of the drink, one of his frequent customers.

title: Brooklyn
instruction:
Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir for up to 2 minutes until well chilled. Strain into a chilled martini glass, coupe or nick & nora and serve.
The original recipe calls for Amer Picon or angostura bitters, but the most reasonable substitution is orange bitters because it is widely available.
description: The Brooklyn is like a standard manhattan in recipe design, but created more dry by using a dry vermouth instead; Not too unlike how a dry martini and standard martini are cousins. Over the years the manhattan dominated the scene and the Brooklyn died away.

title: Caipiroska / Capivodka
instruction:
Put lime quarters in the bottom of an Old Fashioned glass and add sugar over the lime quarters. Muddle the lime with the sugar using a muddler as this will score the lime skin against the sugar grains and extract additional oils from the skin.
Once the limes are crushed into the sugar grains, fill the glass three quarters full with crushed ice then fill with vodka and give it a stir.
description: The Caipiroska is a variation on the more historically popular Brazilian cocktail known as the Caipirinha. The original Caipirinha was designed around 1918.

title: Cape Codder
instruction: Build over ice in a tall glass and garnish! We suggest cranberry juice cocktail for this drink, one with a bit of sugar to tame the tart (not fresh pressed cranberries).
description: The base cape codder recipe design was conceived in 1945 by the Ocean Spray Cranberry Grower's cooperative to drive sales of cranberry juice. A flavorful mix of cranberry and vodka!

title: Champagne Cocktail
instruction:
Add dashes of bitters to your sugar cube and place in the bottom of a champagne glass. Pour champagne/prosecco/sparkling wine into your wine glass.
Garnish and serve!
description: A great new years even cocktail for those that want to experience champagne a bit differently from normal.

title: Chicago South Side
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker (including mint) for 10 seconds and double strain into a chilled coupe glass, garnish with 1 mint leaf.
description: Not to be confused with the single-word form of the “Southside”, the Chicago South Side is a similar variation that brings Angostura into the mix. Unlike the Southside, however, this cocktail calls for lime juice over lemon juice and London Dry Gin over American Gin.

title: Chrysanthemum
instruction: Stir all ingredients in a mixing glass until chilled (up to 2 minutes) and strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish. Use a good vermouth on this cocktail.
description: Published in Hugo Ensslin's 1916 Recipes for Mixed Drinks, Hugo knew what he was doing with this crazy little number. Such a strange pairing of flavors that "just works."

title: Clover Club
instruction: Dry shake all ingredients (without ice) for 15 seconds, add ice and shake again for 10 seconds; strain into a chilled coupe glass, garnish with 3 raspberries on a spear.
description: This cocktail is also documented in the 1931 publication Old Waldorf Bar Days by Albert Stevens Crockett (page 127). In this publication, the cocktail was designed as a rum-based recipe with a bit of grenadine.

title: Common Man Sour
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled nick & nora glass, no garnish required.
description: An experimental drink created on the set of Common Man Cocktails to demonstrate you can take a few random ingredients and build a balanced cocktail with just a bit of math and science (and taste); Yep, it's a "2:1:1" recipe!

title: Corpse Reviver #2
instruction: Add absinthe to chilled coupe and swirl it around the glass and discard remaining absinthe (known as a "rinse"). Build remaining ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into chilled coupe and serve.
description: The corpse reviver #2 is the second version of the corpse reviver and often considered the best version. Designed as a cure-all for a hangover. This rendition was born around 1871.

title: Cosmopolitan
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled Nick & Nora Glass or Martini Glass. Garnish with a lime wheel and serve.
description: The Cosmo was officially created in 1987 by a bartender in Manhattan. However, there are others that lay claim to similar recipes such as the Cape Codder/Harpoon cocktail, a recipe published on the back of Ocean Spray Cranberry Juice cocktail.

title: Cucumber Basil Lime Gimlet
instruction: Muddle basil, cucumber, and lime juice together at the bottom of a cocktail shaker. Add the remaining ingredients and add ice to the shaker. Shake cocktail for 10 seconds and double strain over fresh ice into your Old Fashioned glass.
description: This is a great introductory basil cocktail, which have grown in popularity over the years (especially when paired with gin).

title: Daiquiri
instruction:
Add all ingredients into your cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 10 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass or over ice into an old fashioned glass and enjoy. Optional garnish would include a lime twist.
We call for "rum", generically, because the daiquiri works with all your favorites from a light rum to an aged rum or even a Demerara rum.
description: The daiquiri is a classic island cocktail invented a dozen times by dozens of people. It's so simple that it's a perfect rum sour design.

title: Dark 'N Stormy ™
instruction: Add ice to your glass, followed by rum, and than ginger beer. Garnish with a lime wedge and serve.
description: One of the only trademarked cocktails, the Dark 'N Stormy requires the use of Gosling's Black Seal Rum to be legitimately called by this name.

title: Davy Jones's Locker
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds, strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass and garnish with a lime.
description: Created by New York City bartender Brad Farran as a tribute to the Beastie Boys album "Licensed to Ill"

title: Dead Bastard
instruction: Add all ingredients except ginger beer to a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Slowly stir ginger beer into your cocktail shaker to integrate. Then dump entire contents of your cocktail shaker into a double old fashioned glass. Garnish with mint sprig and orange slice.
description: In 1959 he came up with a couple hangover remedies which he called Dying Bastard and Dead Bastard while working at the Marco Polo Club in Manhattan.

title: Demerara Dry Float
instruction:
Add all ingredients except the overproof rum together in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake aggressively for 15 seconds. Strain over ice into an old fashioned glass and carefully top (pour over the back of a spoon) with overproof rum.
We suggest an overproof dark rum such as LemonHart 151 for this drink; a clear overproof rum won't look as pretty.
description: This tiki drink was created by Don the Beachcomber, circa 1941. It brings passion fruit together with a rum, light on spirit but the spirits involved are fairly strong.

title: Dirty Martini
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass and stir for 30 seconds to 2 minutes. Strain into a chilled nick and nora glass and garnish with one or three olives.
description: The Dirty Martini takes a standard gin martini and brings in a bit of olive brine, which brings additional salt which changes the overall flavor profile.

title: Disaronno Wears Cavalli Sour
instruction: Add lemon juice, simple syrup and disaronno to a cocktail shaker and shake for 10 seconds. Strain into a champagne flute and top with Prosecco. Float 10 dashes of bitters on top and garnish.
description: This cocktail was designed by Disaronno to promote their Cavalli partnership in which the Amaretto bottle was re-designed in the style of Roberto Cavalli.

title: Doctor Funk
instruction: Shake all ingredients except club soda with ice for 15 seconds. Dump shaker contents into pilsner glass, tiki mug or favorite drinking vessel. Top with club soda, add more ice if needed.
description: This drink is made differently in many locations, including the Donn Beachcomber's own locations (circa 1953). However club soda was a late edition added by Jeff Berry in his book vs. the original recipe which called for a blender and crushed ice.

title: Drunken Pimento
instruction: Add all ingredients except ginger ale to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over ice into an old fashioned glass and top with ginger ale. Garnish with a lime wheel.
description: The Drunken Pimento was created by Jennifer and Derrick Schommer for the Boston Jerkfest cocktail competition for the Rumson's Brand of rum.

title: Dying Bastard
instruction: Add all ingredients except ginger beer to a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Slowly stir ginger beer into your cocktail shaker to integrate. Then dump entire contents of your cocktail shaker into a double old fashioned glass. Garnish with mint sprig and orange slice.
description: In 1959 Joe Scialom came up with a couple hangover remedies which he called Dying Bastard and Dead Bastard while working at the Marco Polo Club in Manhattan. These would be variations to the suffering bastard.

title: East India Gimlet
instruction:
Add ice and water to a coupe glass to chill and set aside. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake aggressively for 15 seconds. Dump water/ice from coupe and pour contents from your shaker into the coupe glass.
Garnish with a sprig of dill and serve.
description: Carl Brown's herbal creation which is a variation on the traditional gin gimlet, we make it with real sour not lime concentrate.

title: East Side
instruction: Muddle cucumber in the bottom of your cocktail shaker along with simple syrup and mint. Add the remaining ingredients to the shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Double strain (with a tea strainer) into your glass and garnish with a mint leaf.
description: The east side, a play off the 'south side' cocktail and still remains a gin based drink.

title: Easy Pina Colada
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a martini / coupe glass and serve! Easy!
description: An easy piña colada cocktail that doesn't require the use of coconut cream and a messy build, or blender. Simple. Easy.

title: Espresso Vodka Martini
instruction:
Brew a pot of fresh coffee or espresso (if you like your drinks strong) and let it cool. Add coffee liqueur and vodka in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 10 seconds. Strain into a martini glass and top with fresh coffee.
For a more potent coffee flavor, use cold brewed coffee.
description: There are a few dozen ways to build an espresso martini, this is one of them and it tastes great.

title: Fog Cutter
instruction: Add all ingredients but the Sherry into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Dump contents of shaker into a fog cutter glass (or tall highball) and float sherry on top. Garnish, straw, and serve.
description: This WWI-era cocktail is what most would consider the Long Island Iced Tea of Tiki as designed by Trader Vic. Vic said this drink doesn't cut the fog as much as it creates one.

title: French 75
instruction: Shake all ingredients (except Champagne) vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a champagne flute. Top with champagne and garnish with a lemon twist, serve.
description: Some dedicated cocktail historians will tell you it was originally made with cognac over gin, but that’s still highly contested. Initially created at the New York Bar in Paris, the alcohol kick is like being shelled by a French 75mm field gun and thus you have “The French 75.”

title: French Martini
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled Nick and Nora glass. Note: This cocktail calls for fresh pressed pineapple juice.
description: Created in the 1980s at one of Keith McNally's New York City bars, it's "French" because of the use of Chambord for the raspberry/blackberry flavor.

title: Frozen Mudslide
instruction:
Add two scoops of vanilla ice cream (around 6 ounces) and remaining ingredients to a blender with ice and blend until smooth (roughly 10-15 seconds). Garnish your old fashioned glass with chocolate syrup swirls and pour into your glass.
Optionally add chocolate shavings and whipped cream.
description: A beautiful blended cocktail that lands on the sweeter side and may be a gateway cocktail for future discovery.

title: Gin and Juice
instruction: Add ice to a tall glass, add gin and juice. You can select your own "juice", but our recipe is slightly more unique than a simple greyhound (grapefruit juice).
description: The Gin & Juice, made famous by Snoop Dogg in his lyrics. Some of the best classic cocktails get well known by general audiences from famous personalities. It's simple, it's worthy.

title: Gin Campari Sour
instruction:
Combined all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with egg white and dry shake aggressively for 30 seconds (no ice). Once complete, add ice to the cocktail shaker and shake again for 15 seconds.
Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with citrus (either an orange wheel or lemon wheel).
description: The Gin Campari Sour makes a good valentine's day cocktail as it comes in pink, has a sour tart bite and a lingering bitter.

title: Gin Fix
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass or martini glass. Garnish with a orange slice and serve.
description: You can create a “Fix” with any core spirit, as documented on page 135 of How To Mix Drinks by Jerry Thomas. Most accurately, a “fix” is typically served shaken with ice and served over ice, while a sour is shaken with ice but served in a chilled glass without ice.

title: Gin Fizz
instruction: Dry shake all ingredients except club soda (without ice) for 15 seconds, add ice and shake again for 10 seconds; strain over ice into a lowball glass. Top with Club Soda. Serve immediately.
description: The original Gin Fizz recipe was published in 1862 by Jerry Thomas, The Bartender’s Guide: How To Mix Drinks. Similar to that of a Gin Fix but with less ice and more fizz (carbonation).

title: Gin Gimlet
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass and garnish.
description: This cocktail design was utilized in the mid-1800s as a medical solution. There is evidence of these ingredients being used by the British Royal Navy as a solution to scurvy dating to around 1857.

title: Gin Gin Mule
instruction: Muddle simple syrup, lime juice, and 8 mint leaves in the bottom of your shaker tin. Add gin and top with ice, then shake for 15 seconds. Double strain (with tea strainer to remove any mint) over fresh ice in a tall glass.Top with ginger beer and garnish with a fresh new mint sprig. Server with a straw.
description: Designed by Audrey Saunders for Pegu Club as a way to help get vodka drinkers into a gin cocktail; think moscow mule but more flavor (and slightly sweeter)

title: Gin & Jam
instruction:

into your chilled coupe glass and serve.
description: A good gin based cocktail utilizing

title: Gin Martini
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir for 30 seconds. Using a julep strainer (or hawthorne strainer if it fits), strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass. Optional olive (or 3) as garnish.
description: One historical theory behind the Martini is that it was all born out of a modified Martinez cocktail in California during the 1800s gold rush. A variation on this theory involves a miner on their way to Martinez California requesting a drink and the Martini was born.

title: Gin & Orange Special
instruction: Add all ingredients over ice into a tall glass and serve. Simple! The key to the flavors of this cocktail is the use of fresh pressed orange juice, it just doesn't compare to bottled OJ.
description: This drink does not have a formal history, as a matter of fact, we don't know where it came from (it was a fan submission) but it was tasty and worthy of our database.

title: Gin & Tonic
instruction: In a tall glass, pour gin over cubes of ice. Squeeze a lime wedge and drop it into the glass followed by tonic water and serve.
description: In the 1700s, high doses of quinine were diluted with water to prevent malaria, but was still extremely bitter and hard for people to drink. To make this medicated solution more palatable they added lime, sugar and gin and the early Gin & Tonic was born.

title: Gold Rush
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice for 15 seconds. Strain over fresh ice into an old fashioned glass.
description: A cocktail from Milk & Honey bar, a take on a whiskey sour with honey instead of simple syrup.

title: Golden Cadillac
instruction:
Chill a cocktail glass or Nick & Nora glass with ice and water; leave sitting while you build the drink.
Add all ingredients to a shaker tin with ice; shake for 15 seconds. Dump ice and water from your glass and strain contents of the shaker into your chilled glass; add a dusting of cinnamon on top and serve.
Or, if you're really into it, use a blender on high!
description: And after dinner cocktail designed at Poor Red's in El Dorado California.

title: Greenpoint
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled, usually around 2 minute. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a lemon twist.
description: Another neighborhood cocktail with rye, that riff's off the manhattan and all those other manhattan variations, this cocktail brings "green" in the form of chartreuse

title: Greyhound
instruction:
Build over ice in a tall glass and serve. If there is extra room in the glass, you can always double the ratio to fill out the glass.
Prior to 1945, in the United States at least, most cocktails contained gin instead of vodka so many classics like the Greyhound were gin-based utilizing similar ratios.
description: First documented in the 1930’s Savoy Cocktail book as “a variation of the Grapefruit Cocktail” which utilized gin as the core spirit. A “Greyhound” cocktail also appears in Harper’s Magazine in 1945 stating “The cocktails were made of vodka, sugar, and canned grapefruit juice–a greyhound.”

title: Hanky Panky
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled (usually up to 2 minutes). Strain into a chilled martini glass, add an orange twist, and serve.
description: This cocktail was created by Ada Coleman, head bartender at the American Bar in The Savoy, London in 1925. Ada was one of the first influential women bartenders and one of two that held position of Head Bartender at the Savoy.

title: Harvey Wallbanger
instruction: Add ice to your tall glass and follow it up with vodka and fresh squeezed orange juice. Float Galliano on top, add a straw and garnish. Serve.
description: A cocktail with a mysterious history which often involves a guy named Harvey. That history isn't really legit, but it sounds good.  Created by Donato "Duke" Antone in 1952.

title: Hawaiian Slammer
instruction: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice and shake aggressively for 15 seconds, strain over ice into a tall hi-ball glass and add maraschino cherries on an umbrella. Serve.
description: We have no idea the origin of this drink, we really didn't know if it was even a worthy drink, then we made it. It's fun, what more do you need?

title: Hemingway Daiquiri
instruction:
Add all ingredients to an iced cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe/cocktail glass and serve.
Also been called Daiquiri #3.
description: First created by Constantino Ribalaigua Vert in Cuba, this Daiquiri variation is often referred to as the Hemingway Daiquiri or Daiquiri #3

title: High Fashion Cocktail
instruction: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over ice into your glass and garnish.
description: A beautiful flavor experience for the spring or fall, highlighting the elderflower and rhubarb combination.

title: Hot Toddy
instruction:
Prepare your mug by adding additional boiling water to your mug to warm it up quickly. Once warm/hot empty your mug and add lemon juice, honey bourbon (or regular bourbon) and top with hot water.
To prepare a studded lemon peel, cut your peel and poke 3 whole cloves through the peel and add it to your drink. Add a cinnamon stick and serve.
If you do not have honey bourbon we suggest your favorite bourbon and, if you desire honey, add a
bar spoon
of honey to your finished drink and stir (helps to remove it from the spoon as well).
description: The hot toddy is as hold as home remedies and does not come in a true formal recipe, however most recipes over the last 100 years do suggest a whiskey, lemon and usually a honey or sweetener to help aid a sore throat.

title: Hotel Nacional
instruction:
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds aggressively (to build a nice pineapple foam). Strain into a chilled coupe glass and serve.
Alternatively this works great with a dark rum.
description: A signature cocktail of Havana's Hotel Nacional de Cuba. This cocktail can be made with both light rum and dark rum depending on your favorite rum style. We love dark rum for this one!

title: Hurricane
instruction: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into an iced Hurricane Glass or Hi-Ball. Garnish and serve.
description: The story involves a surplus of rum in the market. In the mid-1940s, shortly after World War II ended, bourbon and Scotch whisky were in short supply. Rum, however, was plentiful. That gave rise to the invention of the Hurricane

title: Irish Coffee
instruction: Fill mug with hot water to preheat it, then empty. Pour hot coffee into the warm glass to about 3/4 full and then stir in brown sugar until dissolved. Add your Irish Whiskey of choice, and top with whipped cream. Serve hot.
description: The Irish Coffee was created in the winter of 1943 by Joe Sheridan, it may not be exact to spec but the concept is fairly straight forward.

title: Java Tai
instruction: Brew strong coffee / espresso and let it cool. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and "dry shake" (without ice) for 20 seconds aggressively. Add ice to your cocktail shaker and shake for an additional 15 seconds and strain into a chilled coupe glass.
description: A great after tiki drinking desert cocktail, either a starter or finisher for the tiki party. We don't know where this cocktail came from, but it's plenty good.

title: Jungle Bird
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over ice into an old fashioned glass. You can garnish with a pineapple wedge and pineapple leaf if you have them hanging around.
description: This classic Tiki drink was created in 1978 at the Aviary bar of the Kuala Lumpur Hilton. This drink brings campari to tiki design but stays true to beach sipper flavor profile.

title: Kamikaze
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass or Martini Glass.
description: This drink was a child of the 70’s, arriving a decade before the Cosmopolitan hit the bar room. Cocktail historian David Wondrich says the history of the Kamikaze can be traced by to 1976.

title: Kentucky Chocolate
instruction:
Add all all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and dry shake (no ice) for 20 seconds aggressively. Add ice to the shaker and shake again for 15 seconds and strain over ice into an old fashioned glass.
Optionally garnish with a lemon wheel.
Works fantastic with a higher proof bourbon, we typically build with Elijah Craig Bourbon.
description: A cocktail design by Jennifer Schommer for one of our Patreon members for the cocktail Youtube channel Common Man Cocktails.

title: Krakatoa
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Use fresh ice, crushed ice or dump the old ice from your cocktail shaker into your highball glass and serve. Garnish with fresh fruit if you so desire. It's tiki, get crazy.
description: The Krakatoa is no doubt some old tiki drink modified over the years, this cocktail is similar to one we've seen published by Jeff Berry, but without actual coffee included (circa 1960)

title: Kraken Hattan
instruction: Add all ingredients (except cherry syrup) into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass, and add cherry juice so it sinks to the bottom. Garnish and serve.
description: Imagine a manhattan like drink designed with spiced rum,

title: Lemon Drop
instruction:
Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 20 seconds (to help integrate the sugar) and strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass or Martini Glass. Cut a lemon twist over the glass to add additional oils and drop twist into the glass.
Optionally you can omit the sugar from the drink and rim the glass, but this can create a sticky mess and not integrate as well into the drink.
description: It is said that this recipe arrived sometime in the 1970s by Norman Jay Hobday in San Francisco. The cocktail represents the flavor profile of the 1878 Lemon Drop candy, or that’s the theory of its inception.

title: Lion's Tail
instruction: Add all your ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and give it a hardy shake for 15 seconds, strain into a coupe glass or nick and nora glass. Garnish with a slice of orange or other citrus.
description: The Lion's Tail appears in “The Café Royal Cocktail Book,” published in 1937. The creator is lost to history, was it the author of the book or a barkeep somewhere in the world? We may never know.

title: Long Island Iced Tea
instruction: Fill a highball glass with ice and add all ingredients except coca-cola. Top with coke, best when Mexican (sugar cane) based coca-cola is used. If you do not have sour mix available, you can use equal parts sugar and fresh lemon juice.
description: The traditional long island iced tea, designed with "five whites"  mingled with sour mix and cola.

title: Los Zelda
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass. You can use Aphrodite Bitters if you have them, or other bitters that bring some level of coffee and cocoa nibs.
description: This cocktail brings another great mezcal drink to your resume, and pairs apple juice with mezcal and passion fruit.

title: Luau
instruction:
Add contents to a cocktail shaker with ice (or crushed ice) and shake aggressively for ten seconds. You can either pour over fresh crushed ice or dump right into your tiki mug. Serve!
To impress, garnish with orchids and citrus and an umbrella.
description: The Luau cocktail was sent to us, seems a bit of research suggests mixologist Gerry Corcoran of PDT created it. We suggest creating this recipe with a good overproof rum, something too rich might be distracting and bacardi overproof is just bad, something in between would be great!

title: Madras
instruction: Build over ice in a tall glass and garnish with an orange wheel and serve. Alternatively, you can layer the ingredients with orange juice, cranberry juice, and a vodka float to give it a pretty presentation (although slightly disjointed taste).
description: The Madras falls into the same category as the Sea Breeze, Bay Breeze, and Cape Codder and set the stage for one of the most popular cocktails of all time: The Cosmopolitan.

title: Barrel o' Rum
description: This cocktail works best in a barrel tiki mug because it fits the motif; This design is from the Mai Kai Restaurant, one of the Historic Places in Florida, best tiki bar in the world says some fans.

title: Mai Tai
instruction:
Add all ingredients to an iced cocktail shaker and shake for 10-15 seconds. Pour into your glass over crushed ice and garnish.
Note: No amber (aged) Martinique Rum & Dark Jamaican Rum? We suggest using a standard aged rum in the recipe as a substitution. So, instead of 1 oz / 30 ml of two rums, do 2 oz / 60 ml of your aged rum instead (Denizen Merchant's Reserve Rum is perfect for this recipe).
description: The classic trader vic Mai Tai first designed in 1953. This historical variant uses two rums to replace the out of production 80 Proof Wray & Nephew Rum.

title: Manchester Cocktail
instruction: Shake all ingredients in a cocktail shaker for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora, garnish with a lime wheel and serve.
description: A cocktail design by Jennifer Schommer, created to riff-off the Dorchester cocktail, but in our home city of Manchester, NH.

title: Manhattan
instruction: Add all the ingredients into a mixing glass halfway filled with ice. Stir until well-chilled and strain into a chilled coupe or martini glass. Garnish with a cherry.
description: The story goes that this cocktail was invented at NYC's Manhattan Club circa 1880. The drink, today, is pretty much identical (while the whiskey flavor profiles have no doubt changed in 100+ years). This has been in fashion, out of fashion, more times than bell bottoms.

title: Margarita
instruction:
Add all ingredients into your cocktail shaker with ice. Shake for 15 seconds and strain over ice into an old fashioned glass and garnish. Optionally, rim your glass with salt.
For a slightly sweeter experience, utilize crushed ice to chill down the cocktail faster and colder. For a more sour experience, tailer back your agave nectar by a quarter ounce (or 7.5ml).
description: There are a wide variety of margarita recipes from super sour to super sweet, but this falls somewhere right in the middle, if slightly sweeter

title: Martinez
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled coupe glass.
description: The Martinez was either the father to the Martini, a cousin to the Martini, a variation, or just a drink created around the same time period. Both the Martini and the Martinez were born between 1860 and 1870 as vermouth became more popular in the United States.

title: Mezcal Mai Tai
instruction: Add all ingredients over ice in a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds and dump into a double old fashioned glass. If you want to stay traditional to the original Mai Tai, use half a spent lime as a garnish.
description: The Mai Tai is a forever fabulous and popular drink, this version brings the Orgeat and lime but does not match the exact Mai Tai recipe. This is a modification of a modification slightly tweaked (by us) to be less sweet.

title: Miami Vice
instruction:
Create both a Piña colada and the Strawberry Daiquiri separately. Then, pour your pina colada into a glass and stack the strawberry daiquiri on top. Stir a bit to look cool and serve.
Stack in a highball glass or hurricane glass if you have one available.
description: Popular pool side in Cancun, Punta Cana and anywhere with resorts -- stack two drinks together!

title: Mimosa
instruction:
Add orange juice to your glass and top with champagne. Optionally, add a little bit of orange bitters and a bit of grand mariner for a great citrus experience.
Note: if you really love champagne cocktails, you may opt to add double the champagne listed in the ingredients.
description: The mimosa was said to be invented by Frank Meier in 1925. It's said to be named after the yellow flower by the same name common in Europe.

title: Mind Eraser
instruction: Add coffee liqueur and vodka over ice into a tall glass and top with club soda. Straw and serve.
description: A breakfast cocktail or night cap, the mind eraser is a design for those looking to loose their inhibitions.

title: Mojito
instruction:
Add your lime wedges and sugar to your tall glass, and muddle them together. Slap ('spank') your mint and add it into your glass over your muddled lime and sugar. Give it a gentle muddle without tearing your mint.
Add crushed ice over the ingredients until you're about halfway up the glass. Then top with light rum and integrate the ingredients by stirring with a bar spoon.
Top with additional crushed ice and top with club soda. Add your garnish and a straw and serve.
description: A classic cocktail born out of Havana Cuba that has survived for almost one hundred years. This old classic is still requested at bars, pool parties and resorts.

title: Monte Carlo
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir for 30 seconds to a minute, strain over fresh ice into a lowball glass, or straight up into a coupe glass.
description: First published in1948 as part of David Embury’s “The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks.", this drink is a riff off the traditional manhattan, but substituting benedictine for vermouth; there is no known origin or author for this classic recipe.

title: Moscow Mule
instruction: Build in a copper mug (for tradition) or old fashioned glass if no mug is available and add your garnish.
description: The Moscow Mule is said to have been invented in 1941 and largely considered the cocktail that sparked the popularity of vodka in the United States. It pairs ginger beer with vodka and a bit of lime acidity.

title: Mr. Bali Hai
instruction:
Add all ingredients with crushed ice into a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Dump contents into a double old fashioned glass or, if you've got one, a Mr. Bali Hai Tiki Mug (vintage) and serve.
Note: If you don't own coffee brandy, use a coffee liqueur instead (which is much the same, but with a rum base).
description: Circa 1953. Like almost every tiki drink on the planet, this recipe has gone through mutations over the last 50+ years.

title: Nacional Daiquiri
instruction: Add all ingredients with ice into a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a lime wedge.
description: With the origin Hotel Nacional, this drink is based in Cuba -- Havana, specifically, but so many daiquiri designs can be created off the original. This recipe was modified by Jeffrey Morgenthaler

title: Navy Grog
instruction:
Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker and shake vigorously with ice cubes, strain into double old fashioned glass with ice-cone around straw.
To make ice cone "garnish", pack crushed / snow ice into a pilsner glass and poke a chopstick in the middle and allow it to refreeze. Pull it out and use that as your cone when ready.
description: By Don Beachcomber circa 1941. Snow cone design by barman Tony Ramos (taught to Jeff Berry in the 1990s). Tony Ramos created the tiki drink the "Hawaiian Eye" as the cast members of the show took over the bar 4 to 5 nights in a row after filming scenes in Waikiki.

title: Negroni
instruction: Build over ice in a double old fashioned glass and garnish with half a wheel of orange.
description: The Campari is a well known cocktail for those that like bitter drinks and, because it's easy to remember. Very few variations exist for this 1:1:1 drink design.

title: New York Sour
instruction: Add all ingredients but red wine to a cocktail shaker without ice and dry shake aggressively for 15 seconds. Add ice to your shaker and shake again for 15 seconds and strain over ice into an old fashioned glass. Float red wine on top and serve.
description: Apparently this 1870's cocktail was first called the Continental Sour and eventually Southern Whiskey Sour before finally being dubbed the New York Sour.

title: Norwegian Wood
instruction: Add ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir for 30 seconds. Strain into a chilled cocktail / coupe glass and garnish with a lemon peel.
description: Jeffrey Morgenthaler design for those of us that want a fall seasonal cocktail that doesn't get pumpkin spice all up in your face

title: Nui Nui
instruction: Pour all ingredients into a shaker with ice and shake for 10 seconds. Strain contents into highball glass with ice.
description: The Nui Nui balances allspice, clove, cinnamon and other trade spices for a great introduction tiki drink for new and old cocktail enthusiasts.

title: Oaxacan Dead
instruction: Build in a tall glass and swizzle with crushed ice. Optionally, garnish with umbrella picked cherry and lime wheel.
description: Pronounced "wah-hock-en" Dead, this cocktail is a play on words from the comic book / tv series and has a great use of Mezcal

title: Old Fashioned
instruction:
Add sugar cube to an old fashioned glass and soak it with bitters of your choice (we prefer
Boy Drinks World Walnut Bitters
but you can use Angostura as well).
Once you've added your bitters to the sugar, muddle the sugar cube into the glass with a
muddler
and then pour your rye (or bourbon) into the glass. Add a couple cubes of ice and stir to dilute ice down a bit and integrate the bitter sugars.
Optionally, garnish with an orange wheel and maraschino cherry.
description: Potentially the first cocktail that started it all, the old fashioned is a simple drink that dates to around 1850, first published in 1860. Our recipe is the original old fashioned, no muddled fruit or cherries, just the raw basics.

title: Paloma
instruction:
Rim a highball with salt and add ice. Follow through with tequila, lime juice and top with your grapefruit soda. Some grapefruit soda may make your Paloma pink, others a tint of yellow.
More advanced / tequila lovers may reduce the grapefruit soda ratio to 4 ounces (120ml) to bring out more tequila notes.
description: Said to be designed by Don Javier Delgado Corona, owner of the beloved La Capilla bar in Jalisco. Credited with the Batanga cocktail as well. Often made with Jarritos or Q Grapefruit; if not, use Fresca or Squirt.

title: Paper Plane
instruction: Add all your ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a paper plane.
description: The paper plane is one of the only cocktails that utilizes a folded airplane for its garnish and is a riff off the Last Word

title: Passion Fruit Daiquiri
instruction: Build all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds, strain into your coupe glass and serve.
description: The Passion Fruit Daiquiri is a riff off a traditional daquiri but with a bit more sour bite and passion fruit tartness.

title: Passion Fruit Drop
instruction: Build all ingredients in a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a sugared lemon.
description: A riff off the traditional lemon drop "martini" that tastes like a lemon drop candy, but with passion fruit instead. No history with this one, just fun taste experiences.

title: Pearl Diver
instruction: Add all the ingredients into a blender with 1/2 cup crushed ice and blend on high for 20 seconds or until a nice rich foam appears. Strain (or dump if you are being lazy) into a tiki mug or Pearl Diver glass if you can find one. Top with crushed ice and garnish with an orchid and pineapple leaf. We also used an old fashioned glass because it was simple.
description: The Pearl Diver is a Donn Beachcomber original that was rediscovered by Jeff Berry after finding a notebook of former Donn Beach Maitre d’, Dick Santiago. Historical search, decoding, and publishing this hidden gem of a cocktail.

title: Pearl Harbor
instruction:
Add ice to a lowball or highball, then add vodka over the ice followed by midori liqueur. Top with the pinepple juice and either stir it (for it to taste great) or leave it layered (to look great).
Want to add a more interesting twist? Add
Fee Brothers Rhubarb Bitters
for a great spring time flare.
description: The Pearl Harbor is one of the only vodka cocktails we enjoy, it's like a Melon Ball but using pineapple juice over orange juice. Might not be classic, but a worthy contender.

title: Penicillin
instruction:
Muddle fresh ginger in a cocktail shaker and add the remaining ingredients (except the Islay Scotch Whisky) and shake with ice for 15 seconds. Double strain with a
tea strainer
over ice into your glass. Top with single malt Islay Scotch and garnish with candied ginger.
description: Created by New York bartender Sam Ross, this cocktail was no doubt designed with autumn/fall in mind. It has all the medicinal qualities of a fall warming cocktail.

title: Pieces of Eight
instruction: Build all ingredients in your cocktail shaker with crushed ice. Shake quickly for about five seconds and dump contents into a tall glass and garnish.
description: Pieces of Eight, a cocktail designed at the Pieces of Eight Restaurant back in the 1962. This cocktail plays off the restaurant name and nautical theme of pirates, booty and treasure. And, financing.

title: Pina Colada
instruction: Add all ingredients to a blender and blend for 10 to 15 seconds. Optionally, add a maraschino cherry garnish if you'd like!
description: The classic pina colada, it's a mystery as to why a drink like this works because it has no sour component. But, who cares? It works!

title: Pinky Gonzales
instruction: Shake & Dump (with ice) into an old fashioned glass, garnish with spent lime & mint sprig.
description: Invented in 1972 by Trader Vic, documented in Trader Vic’s Bartenders Guide using Trader Vic Mai Tai Mix; switch up tequila for blended scotch and this “Mai Tai” variant becomes a Honi Honi cocktail instead.

title: Planter's Punch
instruction: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds and strain into a chilled coupe glass. Use your favorite dark rum for this recipe, we love Plantation Original Dark for this build.
description: Suggested to be originally published in the New York Times in 1908, a recipe from Jamaica, this "punch" has a wide variety of recipe designs, we happen to like this one because it's well crafted and tasty with pool side tropical appeal.

title: Port Light
instruction: Build in blender with crushed ice, blend 5 seconds, dump into old fashioned glass and top with more crushed ice.
description: A rare whiskey based tiki cocktail designed by Sandro Conti from 1961. A whiskey sour meets passion fruit.

title: Pusser's Painkiller ™
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over fresh ice into an old fashioned glass and garnish with a liberal amount of nutmeg.
description: Another child of the 70's with a controversial background. The painkiller became trademarked by Pusser's years after its creation, requiring all bars and restaurants to make a painkiller with Pusser's Rum or risk lawsuit. Created in the British Virgin Islands at the Soggy Dollar bar, now popular everywhere.

title: Ramos Gin Fizz
instruction: Add all ingredients except your ice and club soda to a shaker and shake it without ice (dry shake) for 15 seconds as aggressive as possible. Add ice and shake for 15 seconds or more and strain into a collins glass without ice. Top with club soda and serve.
description: Created in 1888 by Henry Charles “Carl” Ramos at the Imperial Cabinet Saloon in New Orleans. This drink is synonymous with New Orleans, and is supposed to be shaken for 12 to 15 minutes. This raises the price at the bar and consumes a lot of bartender time.

title: Rob Roy
instruction: Add all ingredients to a mixing glass with ice and stir until chilled (usually about 2 minutes). Strain into a chilled coupe or cocktail glass.
description: Invented at the Waldorf Astoria in New York City, this 19th century artwork is a riff off the manhattan. It's simply a manhattan with scotch.

title: Rouge 75
instruction: In a cocktail shaker tin/glass, muddle one orange twist, raspberries and simple syrup. After muddling add gin and ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass and top with champagne. Garnish with remaining lemon twist.
description: We discovered this cocktail for our fall seasonal drinks, we believe the credit goes to a husband-and-wife team in Seattle by the name of Jason and Nicole Wilson.

title: Rum Flower
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds and strain into a chilled coupe glass.
description: A cocktail designed by Jennifer Schommer for the Youtube show Common Man Cocktails.

title: Rum Runner
instruction: Add everything into a cocktail shaker and shake it all for 10 to 15 seconds and strain into a tall glass. Garnish with an orange wheel.
description: The Rum Runner is said to have been a child of the 1950s  at the Holiday Isle Tiki Bar in Islamorada Florida.

title: Rusty Nail
instruction: Add both ingredients to an old fashioned glass and stir. You can serve with ice or "neat" depending on your preference (but chill the glass if you're going to serve it neat).
description: A simple mix concept of Drambuie and Scotch Whisky. This cocktail can be served with or without ice, it's up to you. This cocktail came to light around 1963 and its name stuck when when Gina MacKinnon, the chairwoman of the Drambuie Liqueur Company, gave the Rusty Nail her endorsement.

title: Rye Tai
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake with ice for 15 seconds, strain into an ice filled old fashioned glass and serve. If you want to add some garnish flare, hold your bitters out of the recipe until the end and dash them all on top of the drink to give a white/dark contrasting look!
description: Nick Brown created this cocktail, which no doubt looks a little fancier if you dash all your bitters on top instead of fully integrating; this is a riff off the Mai Tai as it uses rye instead of rum and lemon instead of lime, but fits the "coming into spring" feeling

title: Salty Dog
instruction: Rim a tall glass with salt and set aside. Shake gin and grapefruit juice vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain over ice into your tall rimmed glass. Garnish with a quarter slice of grapefruit and serve.
description: The Salty Dog was invented by George Jessel in 1952. George is the same individual that brought us the well known Bloody Mary cocktail. Given the date of the Salty Dog’s creation, we would not be surprised to find that the original called for vodka over gin.

title: Sazerac
instruction:
Add absinthe to your chilled old fashioned glass, and move it around the base of the glass and along the sides (known as a "rinse") and pour the remaining out. Set glass aside.
Muddle sugar and bitters in a mixing glass and then add rye whiskey. Add ice and stir to chill down for about 2 minutes. Strain into rinsed old fashioned glass; use lemon twist to express oils over drink and on glass. Discard lemon twist.
Note: It's not a mistake, a sazerac isn't served on ice. Just a chilled old fashioned glass.
description: The Sazerac went through many variations as Antoine Amedie Peychaud experimented with remedies that used his bitters. In 1838 it used French Brandy and by 1873 it was using American Rye. It moved from Absinthe to Herbsainte and other slight variations. All great cocktails change with time.

title: Scorpion Bowl
instruction: Add all ingredients to a blender/mixer and blend/mix for 10 seconds and dump all contents into a bowl (or a few glasses). Garnish with a gardenia (if you have one on hand).
description: The Scorpion or "Scorpion Bowl" for the full size, is one of Trader Vic's most popular cocktail recipes, from around 1972.

title: Screwdriver
instruction: Build over ice in a tall glass and add your garnish. Works best with fresh squeezed orange juice.
description: First documented in 1938, this classic mixer was said to be originally stirred with a screwdriver by American Aviators.

title: Sea Breeze
instruction: Build over ice in a tall glass and garnish with lime wedge and serve. Fresh grapefruit juice will give this a smooth mild tartness vs. a more aggressive tartness from bottled grapefruit juice.
description: This cocktail is said to have been invented in the 1920s. Vodka was not introduced into the United States until the 1930s so the original Sea Breeze wold have been designed with gin as the core spirit.

title: Sidecar
instruction:
Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over ice into an old fashioned or into a chilled (no ice) nick & nora glass and garnish.
The recipe balance can be done in many ways and has been over the years. You can also try a 2:1:1 balance or even a 3:2:2 ratio of strong to sweet/sour.
description: The first recipes for the Sidecar appear in 1922, in Harry MacElhone's Harry's ABC of Mixing Cocktails. It is one of six basic drinks listed in David A. Embury's The Fine Art of Mixing Drinks (1948). Ironically this recipe has a ton of variations, this is just one of them.

title: Singapore Sling
instruction:
Add ingredients to a shaker tin with ice and shake for 10 seconds and dump entire shaker contents into a hurricane glass and serve.
Note:
If you don't have hurricane glasses, use a standard highball glass for this recipe. Owning a hurricane glass just for this (and potentially a hurricane cocktail) may be overkill.
description: The very first Singapore Sling recipe said to have been created by Ngiam Tong Boon is lost to time. Not even the Raffles Hotel, who has been serving it since 1915 or so, has the original recipe–they add “this or that” as Jeff Berry says in his book.

description: The "fizz" has existed since 1887 when Jerry Thomas penned his fizz recipes; one can technically turn anything into a fizz, even sloe berry gin, so here you go...a recipe dating to the 1880's with a spirit that matches it in age.

title: Social Season
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake it for 12 seconds, strain it over crushed ice, then add a bit of crushed ice on the top.
description: An interesting cocktail that feels like it may be a riff on a Singapore Sling of sorts.

title: Southside
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker (including mint) for 10 seconds and double strain into a chilled coupe glass and garnish with a single mint leaf.
description: The Southside cocktail has a murky history and a confusing origin city. Is “southside” referring to New York or Chicago? It has also been called “a mint julep with gin” and Dale Degroff says it’s a variation on a cocktail called the Major Bailey which uses both lemon and lime.

title: Spiked Eggnog
instruction:
Chill your old fashioned glass with ice and water. Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker without ice and aggressively shake for 15 seconds. Add ice to your cocktail shaker and shake for another 15 seconds.
Dump your ice and water from your glass and strain contents of shaker into a chilled glass. Garnish and serve.
description: Spiked Eggnog (Eggnog with Alcohol) is a classic winter recipe created by dozens of people, it's pretty straight forward: whole eggs and spirit. This drink is a good starter recipe.

title: Steve's Rum Barrel
instruction: Add all ingredients to an immersion blender with crushed ice, dump into a tiki mug. For Pernod (Absinthe) do 6 drops (roughly 1 dash), for almond extract, do 3 drops (or around that, maybe a dash)
description: From Steve Crane at Kon-Tiki restaurant in the 1960s, a big drink, but a great drink!

title: Stone Wall
instruction: Muddle simple syrup with ginger in a cocktail tin and then add rum, cider and ice. Top your shaker and shake for 15 seconds, double strain the contents into an ice filled rocks glass. Garnish and serve.
description: Dale Degroff designs a cocktail that takes advantage of apple cider and we cannot argue. Invented at the Silver Leaf Tavern in NY.

title: Strawberry Daiquiri
instruction: Add all ingredients to a blender and add six cubes of ice (or around 8 ounces / 1 cup) and blend for 10-15 seconds or until smooth.
description: The Strawberry Daiquiri is a well known blended variation of a traditional daiquiri; there are many strawberry daiquiri recipe designs, we just want the good ones.

title: Suffering Bastard
instruction:
Add all ingredients except ginger beer to a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Slowly stir ginger beer into your cocktail shaker to integrate. Then dump entire contents of your cocktail shaker into a double old fashioned glass.
Garnish with mint sprig and orange slice.
description: Suffering Bastard as designed in Cairo at Shepheard's by Joe Scialom in 1942. This is one of three variations of the suffering bastard series (the original). Follow on's include the dead and dying bastard.

title: Sundowner
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker and shake for 15 seconds. Strain over fresh ice into your old fashioned glass and garnish with an orange slice.
description: There are many varieties of 'sundowner' recipes out there, so we are not sure what the historic significance is on this drink. But, we like the play of campari meets mezcal.

title: Tequila Sour
instruction: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker and dry shake (without ice) aggressively for 15 seconds. Add ice and shake again for 15 seconds then double strain into an old fashioned glass (ice optional). Add three dots of bitters for presentation and serve.
description: The history behind this dates back to the first category of 'sour' and has been modified a bit to be more interesting and fun. This fits more of a "Boston Sour" (whiskey sour with egg white) but with Tequila and sugar/citrus/bitters that pair against the flavor of tequila.

title: Tequila Sunrise
instruction: Add ice to a highball glass and add tequila and orange juice. Sink grenadine to the bottom by slowly pouring it into the drink.
description: The original tequila sunrise used creme de cassis for its sunrise effect along with soda water... the redesigned modern classic comes out of the 70's and was popularized by Mick Jagger of the Rolling stones and later The Eagles.

title: Test Pilot
instruction: Build in a mixing glass or blender with crushed ice, and blend for 5 seconds (or give it a good shake). Dump (do not strain) into a double old fashioned glass and stack with ice, and a cherry. For absinthe, we suggest a dash that's "6 drops" (from a dropper or 2 sprays from an atomizer)
description: A 1941 Don The Beachcomber cocktail recipe that represents the perfect image of tiki

title: The Dorchester
instruction: Shake all ingredients vigorously in a cocktail shaker for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass or martini glass. Garnish with a grapefruit twist and serve.
description: This fantastic cocktail doesn’t have a rich deep history. We believe this was created (or at least documented) by Charles Phan’s Slanted Door.

title: The Last Word
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe or nick & nora glass.
description: The Last Word has a mythical history that begins around 1916 with many folks claiming its creation or its bar menu addition, including the Detroit Athletic club and others. It was brought back to life in 2003 by Murray Stenson when he discovered it in an old cocktail book. He served it at the Zig Zag Cafe.

title: The Polynesian Spell
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 10 seconds and strain over fresh ice into a lowball glass.
description: A 1961 Tiki cocktail based out of Ohio at the Kahiki restaurant in Columbus. Plus, it's purple.

title: Revolver
instruction: Build all ingredients in a mixing glass and stir for about 2 minutes (or until sufficiently chilled) and strain into a chilled nick & nora glass. This drink needs the dilution and chill down time, don't skimp on the stir.
description: This cocktail is designed by San Francisco bartender Jon Santer who apparently loves spirit-forward spicy rye cocktails because this will hit you like a... revolver.

title: The Vesper
instruction:
Chill a large coupe glass with water and ice; set aside.
Add cocktail ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake aggressively for 10 seconds. Dump ice and water from your glass and double strain (to remove ice shards) contents of the shaker into your chilled glass.
Garnish with a lemon peel and serve.
If you can't find Lillet Blanc, you can substitute Cocchi Americano.
description: A drink made famous by Ian Fleming in Casino Royale, another James Bond classic.

title: The White Walker
instruction: Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake aggressively before dumping contents into a highball glass or pilsner class (if you make multiple batches). Top with crushed ice and garnish with your favorite tropical fruits and/or pineapple leaves.
description: This Zombie riff isn't exactly a Game of Thrones cocktail unless you want it to be, but it does fit a great summer time rum friendly desire.

title: Third Rail
instruction: Muddle ginger with agave and lime, add remaining ingredients to an iced cocktail shaker. Shake for 15 seconds and strain into an old fashioned glass.
description: The third rail was first discovered at the Apotheke in Chinatown NYC. We had to re-design the recipe based on the ingredients they had told us about. This is our interpretation.

title: Tom Collins
instruction: Build over ice in a tall glass and top with soda water and gently stir; garnish with a lemon slice, serve.
description: Jerry Thomas turned this prank cocktail into reality in 1876’s The Bar-Tenders Guide (page 91) in which Thomas references the Tom Collins as a Whiskey, Brandy or Gin cocktail by simply changing out the core ingredient in this sour.

title: Trinidad Sour
instruction:
Chill a large coupe glass with water and ice; set aside.
Add cocktail ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 10 seconds. Dump ice and water from your glass and strain contents of the shaker into your chilled glass.
If you fall in love with a Trinidad sour, we suggest a
16 oz bottle of angostura bitters
as you'll be going through bitters quickly.
description: The Trinidad sour is a great use of angostura bitters in high degree, this drink's core "spirit" is bitters and that is pretty unusual.

title: Vodka Collins
instruction: Build over ice in a tall glass and top with soda water and gently stir; garnish with a lemon slice and cherry, serve. Vodka is a rather flavorless core spirit so consider club soda over seltzer water in this drink to give this cocktail a bit of added nuance.
description: The Vodka Collins is a variation of the earlier Tom Collins by simply removing Old Tom Gin and replacing it with vodka. Difford’s Guide suggests that Vodka Collins cocktails were being served in 1933 after the repeal of prohibition.

title: Watermelon Thai Basil Daiquiri
instruction: Add all ingredients to a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 15 seconds. Strain into a chilled coupe glass, garnish and serve. Optionally garnish with a lime wedge.
description: A cocktail design by Max at Cocktail & Sons, the concept is simple, a daiquiri can take on many great flavors and Cocktail & Sons has brought Thai Basil together with watermelon

title: What The Dickens?
instruction: Add all ingredients to a shaker with ice, shake for 15 seconds and strain over ice, garnish with a lime wheel.
description: Cognac cocktail created by Denver bartender Ben Anderson

title: Whiskey Smash
instruction: Cut a half lemon into wedges. In a shaker, muddle the lemon with the simple syrup. Add mint leave and perform a more gentle muddle. Add the remaining ingredients with ice and shake. Dump ice and ingredients into a double old fashioned and add more ice as necessary.
description: A century old recipe design, great for the warm months and easy because you can make up your ingredients. You can find recipes with similar ingredients dating back to Jerry Thomas’ 1862 How to Mix Drinks, or, The Bon Vivant’s Companion but not by name "Whiskey Smash."

title: Whiskey Sour
instruction:
Add ingredients to a shaker tin with ice and shake for 10 seconds. Strain into a chilled lowball glass and serve. Egg White is optional (technically that makes it a Boston Sour, but it's a fantastic edition).
If using egg whites, use the dry shake method (shake all ingredients without ice aggressively for 20-seconds then add ice and shake for 15 seconds).
description: The whiskey sour, a basic sour cocktail ratio with your favorite whiskey, could also be considered a 'Boston Sour' with the inclusion of egg white.

title: White Lady
instruction: Dry shake all ingredients (without ice) for 15 seconds, add ice and shake again for 10 seconds; strain into a chilled coupe glass.
description: This drink’s origin lands somewhere between 1919 and 1930 and has a few folks crediting themselves with its creation. Harry McElhone lays claim to its initial invention at London’s Ciro Club in 1919 while Harry Craddock documented it in his 1930’s Savoy Cocktail Book from the American Bar in London.

title: White Russian
instruction:
Build over ice in an old fashioned glass, adding your cream/milk/half-and-half last so it builds a neat presentation. Optionally, add nutmeg to the top as a garnish.
Some folks opt to shake and strain this beverage, which works perfectly fine as well. You may also opt to swap Half & Half for cream for a thicker consistency or milk for a thinner consistency.
description: The Dude approves of the White Russian. This cocktail is a variation of the Black Russian and appeared around the 1960, 10+ years after the Black Russian. Of course, it blew up when Jeff Bridges drank it in The Big Lebowski

title: Wise Oaxacan Mule
instruction:
Muddle the honey, ginger, lemon and sage. Add whiskey and mezcal. Shake and strain with
tea strainer
into a cup filled with crushed ice. Top with the ginger beer and garnish with sage sprig.
description: A cocktail design by Jennifer Schommer, created for the Moscow Mule company's 75h Anniversary MuleHead recipe book

title: Woo Woo
instruction:
Add all ingredients into a cocktail shaker with ice and shake for 10 seconds. Strain into a chilled Nick & Nora glass or Martini Glass and serve.
Optionally, for a “tall drink”, double the recipe and build it over ice in a Hi-Ball Glass or Collins Glass.
description: The Woo Woo is a cocktail with a shrouded history for such a well known drink. One of the rumored histories noted by Bols Amsterdam was that the cocktail was designed by a bartender at the now closed First Edition bar in Bayside, NY.

title: Zombie (1934)
instruction:
Add all ingredients into a tin with crushed ice and pulse / blend for 5 seconds (we prefer the
Hamilton Beach 730C Classic DrinkMaster Drink Mixer
). Dump contents into a hi ball / collins glass and garnish with a mint sprig (and anything else you want)
This drink calls for roughly six ounces of crushed ice, but use your best judgement. More ice will dilute the drink down a bit, but that's a good thing for a zombie!
description: Designed by Don The Beachcomber circa 1934. This was found by Jeff Berry in one of Don's waiters notebooks from 1937 by the name of Dick Santiago says Jeff Berry in REMIXED. The recipe was marked "old."

title: 18th Century
instruction:
Combine all ingredients over ice and shake for about 30 seconds
Strain into a cocktail glass, no garnish
description:
Based on the 20th Century—an indelible brunch classic that also employs creme de cacao—the 18th century justifies its name-based subtraction exercise by substituting the traditional dry gin for Batavia Arrack, an ingredient that appropriately did hit it’s apex during the 18th century. The official spirit of Java, Batavia Arrack is similar in character to light rum, but differentiates itself with the addition or red rice during the fermentation process. It is most famously known for its use in Arrack Punch, but has seen a bit of a revival in the past decade as more and more historical spirits are resuscitated. New York cocktail mainstay, Death & Co., has shown a particular propensity for the spirit, and there is no better example to us than this recipe, which was published in their popular cocktail book of the same name.
A true multi-season crossover, the 18th century mixes light, sunny notes from lime and arrack with more wintry, indulgent flavors like chocolate and dark fruit. The drink is creamy with a beautiful orange hue that resembles another oddbird classic: the lion's tail. It starts with a whiff of lime and sugarcane—not unlike a good daiquiri—before finishing with a big wash of chocolate that really gives the drink an extra dimension and sense of layers. Employ this drink during winter brunches or warm evenings, as it truly plays well in all seasons.
Arrack is great in this drink but not really identifiable; most drinkers who haven’t been informed will likely be asking what kind of magical rum is used. Since Arrack is primarily distilled from fermented sugarcane just like rum, this is likely to happen in many drinks that utilize it. The original recipe calls for Carpano Antica sweet vermouth, though we rarely keep that label and were just peachy with whatever was around at the time. The recipe recommends Van Oosten Batavia Arrack, which is the standard and we support, though admittedly our experience with the ingredient is limited. As with all of our drinks, we highly recommend using Tempus Fugit creme de cacao as many others are too sweet and don’t have a complex cacao flavor.

title: 20th Century
instruction:
Combine all ingredients with ice and shake
Strain into a coupe, serve up
description:
Conceptually, the 20th Century is a triumph. Its striking name and golden hue evoke images of gilded deco monuments and lavish, confetti filled parties. Created in the 1930s, the drink takes inspiration from the 20th Century Limited train, which set a new standard of luxury. It greeted wealthy metropolitan passengers with the first example of red carpet treatment, exuding an air of exclusivity and sophistication. This cocktail captures a similar sense of modernity and opulence. In short, it tastes like new money.
Creme de cacao is responsible for elevating this cocktail from common to lux, adding just a hint of chocolate that enriches the more traditional gin, citrus, and Lillet combo. Be warned, shelves are full of questionable chocolate liqueurs. Our choice is Tempus Fugit, offering the warmth of cocoa powder and vanilla without the saccharine qualities of alternatives. A dry gin such as Death's Door is best for maintaining balance while Lillet, a classically fashionable favorite, adds luster. The result is a sweet, silky, simple kind of fancy.
The original recipe, recorded in the Cafe Royal Cocktail Book, calls for two parts gin to one part each modifier. This formula benefits from a bit of tinkering. We suggest cutting back on the lemon while drizzling in a touch more gin, because that is never a bad idea.

instruction:
Combine all ingredients in a shaker and shake
Double strain into large, chilled glass filled with ice.
